ClinicalDocument.title: Department of Veterans Affairs Health Summary

text.paragraph: This section contains Allergies on record with VA for the patient. The data comes from all VA treatment facilities. It does not list allergies that were removed or entered in error. Some allergies may be reported in the Immunization section.
This section contains a list of Problems/Conditions known to VA for the patient. It includes both active and inactive problems/conditions. The data comes from all VA treatment facilities.
This section contains the names of all active insurance providers for the patient from all VA treatment facilities.

section.title: Medications Section
section.text: No Data Provided for This Section

text.paragraph: This section contains a list of completed VA Outpatient Encounters for the patient and a list of Discharge Summaries, Consult Notes, and History & Physical Notes for the patient. The data comes from all VA treatment facilities.

The list of VA Outpatient Encounters shows the 25 most recent Encounter dates within the last 36 months. Each VA Outpatient Encounter may also include several notes with the complete note text. There is a limit of 10 notes for each Encounter. Follow-up visits related to the VA Encounter are not included. The data comes from all VA treatment facilities.

Department of Veterans Affairs Medical Center 3710 SW US Veterans Hospital Road Portland, OR 97239
In Reply Refer To: 648/V3PMRS
Date: MAY 30, 2014
FN6 MN6 LN6 2186 NE 9TH AVE
HILLSBORO, OR 97124
Dear FN6 MN6 LN6:
Your health care provider has referred you for Physical Therapy at Portland VA Medical Center.
If you are calling for a Portland Division Physical Therapy appointment, please call 503-273-5018 to schedule your 60 minute appointment. If you are outside the local area, you may call toll free 1-800-949-1004, ext. 55018/55745.
To schedule your 60 minute appointment at the Vancouver Division, please call 360-696-4061, ext. 32222 or ext. 33345. If you are calling from Portland, you may call 503-220-8262, ext. 32222 or ext. 33345. If you are outside the local area, you may call toll free 1-800-949-1004, ext. 32222 or ext. 33345.
If you do not call to schedule this appointment by Jun 30,2014 the consult will be cancelled and returned to your provider.
We look forward to your call and thank you for the opportunity to serve you.
Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation Service

Chief complaint / Reason for Visit:
1) Patient states that right knee pain has NOT gotten better.
CLINICAL REMINDER ACTIVITY *Vitals: Temp: 98.3 F (36.8 C) Pulse: 84 Patient blood pressure recorded. Blood Pressure: 130/90 Weight: 174 lb (79.1 kg)--(without shoes)
O2 SAT: 96% Pain: 7 Location/Duration: Right Knee/Several weeks. Yes, patient is here to have pain/comfort issues addressed at this visit.

PRIMARY CARE OUTPATIENT NOTE: LOCAL TITLE: PC - FOLLOW UP STANDARD TITLE: PRIMARY CARE OUTPATIENT NOTE DATE OF NOTE: MAY 02, 2014@11:48 ENTRY DATE: MAY 02, 2014@11:48:32 AUTHOR: LE,KHOI HA EXP COSIGNER: URGENCY: STATUS: COMPLETED
CC: fu knee pain
SUBJECTIVE:
FN6 MN6 LN6 is a 39yo MALE who is SERVICE CONNECTED 50%
He has R knee pain about 1 month ago after playing basketball; pain on R medial knee. Swelling is resolved now; using knee brace for support. Took naproxen x 2wks as directed. Trying application of ice and also elevation; not tried liniment yet. No problem with walking.
ROS: No bruise.
Past Medical History:
Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (SCT 235Posttraumatic stress disorder (SCT 47505003) Genital herpes simplex (SCT 33839006) Migraine (SCT 37796009) Cervical Radiculopathy (ICD-9-CM 723.4) Alcohol abuse in remission (ICD-9-CM 305.03) Negative for Sickle cell trait (ICD-9-CM 282.5)
Active Medications: 1) Acyclovir 800mg tab take one-half tablet by mouth three times a day as needed for outbreaks 2) Omeprazole 20mg ec cap take one capsule by mouth every morning before breakfast 3) Sumatriptan succinate 50mg tab take one tablet by mouth as needed of headache, may repeat after two hours. max 200mg/24 hours.
ALLERGIES: Known Allergies and Drug Reactions: Reactant Reaction ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ - NONE
Remote Allergy/ADR Data
No Remote Allergy/ADR Data available for this patient
OBJECTIVE VITAL SIGNS: Weight: 174 lb [79.1 kg] (05/02/2014 11:30) BMI: 28.1 (05/02/2014 11:30) Temp: 98.3 F [36.8 C] (05/02/2014 11:30) BP: 130/90 (05/02/2014 11:30) Pulse: 84 (05/02/2014 11:30)
General appearance: sitting in NAD; about stated age; verbal, coherent and appropriate. Musculoskeletal: Knee/hip ROM, though with some guaring and pain when R knee fully flexed. Mild tenderness to palpation on R medial knee. No joint effusion noted. No patellar tenderness. Valgus stress aggravates pain. Drawing tests negative. Weight bearing full. No lower extremity edema or varicosis. Skin: pink, warm and dry. No rash or ecchymosis. Neurologic: Good posture/gait.
ASSESSMENT: R knee pain, likely from MCL sprain, improving.
PLAN: 1. Discussed with and counseled patient about the above issue. 2. Order a course of PT for rehab. 3. Cont icing, elevation. 4. Advised liniment; rx sent. 5. Cont another 2 wks of naproxen. 6. Avoid high impact physical activities. 7. Return to follow up per recall schedule, or sooner as needed.
All questions addressed, including lab results/semen analysis ones.
CLINICAL REMINDER ACTIVITY Elevated Pain Score: Latest pain score reported by patient: 7 (05/02/2014 11:30). CLINICIAN PAIN REASSESSMENT: Comment related to pain reassessment: per a/p
Diabetes or HTN > 139/89: Other Reason: no HTN dx
/es/ Khoi Ha LE MD Signed: 05/02/2014 12:16 ,

Pt calling in wanting the results for stool study done at OHSU and also would like to know what else can be done to see what is wrong with his knee. 04/09/2014 ADDENDUM STATUS: COMPLETED s/o: Vet called back to clinic. vet is requesting results of semen study from OHSU.
vet had right knee injury on 3/26 and seen by PCP 3/27 with xrays done, vet has been using ice application, rest and elevation, naproxen arrived in mail 4/8, so unitl then was taking motrin 800mg BID. Vet has not seen any improvement, cont with constant pain 7-8/10 and increasing to 10/10 with bending or during sleep with he moves and bends knee. vet has also been wearing neoprin brace. vet was at National Guard this weekend and PA there examined him and was unable to do so r/t edema. vet requesting more eval to see what is wrong with his knee.
a/p: fwd to PCP, please advise on semen study results, unclear of abnormal results and what to relay to vet, also vet requesting further eval of knee as it has not improved.

PRIMARY CARE INITIAL EVALUATION NOTE: LOCAL TITLE: PC - INITIAL EVALUATION STANDARD TITLE: PRIMARY CARE INITIAL EVALUATION NOTE DATE OF NOTE: MAR 27, 2014@07:55 ENTRY DATE: MAR 27, 2014@07:55:34 AUTHOR: LE,KHOI HA EXP COSIGNER: URGENCY: STATUS: COMPLETED
*** PC - INITIAL EVALUATION Has ADDENDA ***
Chief Complaint: est care
History of Present Illness: 39 yr old MALE WHITE a new pt to me.
1. Had vasectomy reversal in Palo Alto CA last 3/13. Repeated semen analysis 2 month later showed no sperm; he would like to have another test.
2. Migraine: has this since about 2005; frequency 1-2x per month; lasting from 2h; location frontal, pulsating, w/ vision changes dark spots, blurred vision, nausea, and phopho/photophobia. Taking Sumatriptan 50 mg prn which helps.
3. Gential herpes: he has this since 2000; symp with sore spots; taking acyclovir 400 mg tid x5d prn; frequency of outbreaks q2m; was on preventive tx before but not do this any more.
4. GERD: has acid reflux; was on pill omeprazole before but now not taking pill any more; still has symp. Would like to get back on med.
Had C4-5 fusion done in 05 for neck injury on deployment. Was taking hctz for htn in 06 when in the service for 1 yr but off med since.
Review of Systems: No h/o CVA, seizure, cp, sob, abd pain, n/v, bowel or bladder problem. Played basketball last night and twisted his R knee; some swelling; no bruise; slight numbness. MH a lot better.
Past Medical History:
Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (SCT 235Posttraumatic stress disorder (SCT 47505003) Genital herpes simplex (SCT 33839006) Hypertension (ICD-9-CM 401.9) Migraine (SCT 37796009) Cervical Radiculopathy (ICD-9-CM 723.4)
Active Outpatient Medications (including Supplies):
Sumatriptan Acyclovir.
Medication reconciliation performed with patient/representative and updated med list provided to patient.
Allergies:Patient has answered NKA
Social History Marital Status: MARRIED Two daughter; one son. Service time 93-98 Navy; 98-now national guard. Denied tobacco. Rare etoh about once a month. Denied drug use.
Health Maintenance: PSA:No PROSTATIC SPECIFIC ANTIGEN in the last 5Y Colon Screening: Eye Exam/Dilated Eye Exam: Foot Exam: Immunizations:IMMUNIZATIONS: 03/01/09 TETANUS DIPTHERIA (TD-ADULT) 11/00/13 FLU,3 YRS
Family History: Denied family history of heart attack, stroke, or cancer in first degree family. Mother has DM, HTN, and alive age 60. Father alive age 69. Two brothers, 2 sister.
Physical Exam: Vitals reviewed. General appearance: sitting in NAD; about stated age; verbal, coherent and appropriate. HEENT: head symmetrical. Pupils equal, round and reactive to light. Conjunctiva moist and pink, no injection or icterus. No pharyngeal edema, exudate, or erythema. Trachea midline. Neck supple. No thyromegaly or lymphadenopathy. Cardiac: regular rate and rhymth. No murmur; no rubbing or gallop. Lungs: CTA A and P chest; good inspiratory effort. Abdomen: Soft, non tender; no distention. No HSM or masses. Musculoskeletal: Neck ROM preserved. Some guarding with R knee movements; mild edema R knee with tenderness to palpation on medially; valrus stress test elicited pain medially. No patellar tenderness. Spine straight. No lower extremity edema or varicosis. Skin: pink, warm and dry. No rash or ecchymosis. No cyanosis. Neurologic: able to bear weight; gait limping. Psych: Normal mood and affect; normal behavior, speech/language.
ASSESSMENT: 1. Migraine; infrequent flairs; improved with imitrex. 2. Genital herpes; frequent outbreaks so prophylatic tx reasonable; pt more comfortable with prn acyclovir use. 3. GERD; symptomatic; not on tx. 4. PTSD; in remission. 5. R knee pain, likely MCL sprain. 6. S/p reveral vasectomy.
PLAN: 1. Discussed with and counseled patient about the above issues. 2. Labs ordered: bmp, alt, flp, a1c. 3. Semen analysis per pt's request. 4. Will contact patient with test results. 5. Advised activity modification, icing, elevation, knee brace. Rx 2 wk of naproxen. 6. Xray R knee. 7. Refill imitrex and acyclovir. 8. Restart ppi omeprazole. 9. Return to follow up in 1 yr or sooner as needed.
All questions addressed.
/es/ Khoi Ha LE MD Signed: 03/27/2014 08:57
03/27/2014 ADDENDUM STATUS: COMPLETED I called lab and ordered semen analysis for pt. Please advise pt to call ohsu 503-418-3700 to get instruction on how to submit the specimen. He did once last year and should already know the process.
/es/ Khoi Ha LE MD Signed: 03/27/2014 13:45
Receipt Acknowledged By: 03/27/2014 13:50 /es/ LORRAINE H. KOGA Health Technician ,

GENERAL SURGERY with associated notes
OPERATIVE NOTE: LOCAL TITLE: BRIEF OPERATIVE REPORT 14011 STANDARD TITLE: OPERATIVE NOTE DATE OF NOTE: MAR 01, 2013@15:13 ENTRY DATE: MAR 01, 2013@15:14:06 AUTHOR: EISENBERG,MICHAEL EXP COSIGNER: URGENCY: STATUS: COMPLETED
Preoperative Diagnosis: Vasal occlusion Postoperative Diagnosis: same Procedure performed: bilateral vasovasostomy
Surgeons: Eisenberg, Barbosa
Anesthesia: General, local
Indications: This is a 38 year old male who underwent a vasectomy in the past. He has prior paternity. He is now desires fertility. Risks of bleeding, infection, pain, damage to surrounding structures, failure to reestablish sperm in the ejaculate were explained to the patient who wished to proceed.
Findings: Left - whole nonmotile sperm, opalescent fluid, vas just distal to convoluted Right - whole motile sperm, opalescent fluid, vas just distal to convoluted
Description of procedure:
After obtaining informed consent, the patient was brought into the operating theater. After the induction of general endotracheal anesthesia, the patient was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion in the lower abdominal and genitalia region. Parenteral antibiotics were administered. A time out was performed.
We then turned our attention to the left hemiscrotum. An approximately 5 cm vertical incision was made and the left testis was delivered with the tunica vaginalis intact. After achieving excellent hemostasis, the area of the previous vasectomy site was identified. The vas deferens was first isolated on the testicular side and 5-0 chromic suture was placed through the perivasal tissue as a holding stitch. The vas was then transected using a nerve holder and a denis blade. The cephalad vasal segment was then ligated using a 3-0 chromic suture. Hemostasis was achieved using bipolar electrocautry. Fluid emanating from the testicular vas was aspirated and examined under a microscope. The fluid appeared opalescent with whole, nonmotile sperm.
Attention was now turned towards the abdominal side of the vas. The vas was isolated and a 5-0 chomic perivasal holding stitch was placed. The vas was transected using a nerve holder and dennis blade. The caudal vasal segment was ligated using a 3-0 chromic suture and hemostasis was achieved with bipolar electrocautery. A 5-0 pds suture was placed at the base of the proximal and distal ends of the remaining healthy vasal segments and this was used to reapproximate the two ends. The inner mucosa of both ends of the vas deferens were dilated and both ends appeared to be healthy with good vascularity. Three 9-0 nylon outer layer sutures were placed at the 4, 6, and 8 oclock positions. Next, 3 10-0 nylon inner layer sutures were placed and tied at the 4, 6, and 8 oclock postions. Three more 10-0 nylon inner sutures were first placed at the 10, 12, and 2 oclock position and then these three sutures were tied. There appeared to be excellent reapproximation of the inner mucosa and no leak was identified. Next the outer muscularis layer was reapproximated using inturrupted 9-0 nylon sutures. After excellent hemostasis was achieved, the testicle was placed back into the scrotum and the dartos layer was closed with a running 3-0 chromic suture. The skin edges were reapproximated using inturrupted 3-0 chomic horizontal matress sutures.
An identical procedure was performed on the contralateral side. There the fluid appeared opalescent with whole, motile sperm.
Upon conclusion of the procedure the wounds were cleaned and drapped with a sterile telfa gauze. Scrotal support and fluffs were applied to the scrotum. At the end of the procedure the sponge, instrument and needle count was correct. The patient was awoken and taken to the PACU in stable condition.
Complications: none Specimens: none Drains: none
Disposition: The patient was awoken and taken to the PACU in stable conition.
/es/ Michael Eisenberg, MD Urologic Surgeon Signed: 03/01/2013 15:16

NURSING PLAN OF CARE OR/PACU
1. NURSING PROBLEM - ANXIETY - Anxiety related to surgical procedure and unfamiliar environment EXPECTED OUTCOME - Patient articulates the procedure and what will happen the day of surgery in lay terms environment. NURSING INTERVENTIONS - Provide info regarding pre-op procedure blood transfusion when applicable; NPO, Insertion of catheter, premedication, O.R.equipment, personnel, monitors and environment.
2. NURSING PROBLEM - FINDINGS - Anxiety related to possible surgical findings and past surgical experience. EXPECTED OUTCOME - Patient will manage anxiety as demonstrated by discussing previous experience and relating realistic view of outcome. NURSING INTERVENTIONS - Explain to patient, family, significant other the routine in the O.R.and in the PACU. Encourage patient to ventilate feelings. Explain nursing procedures and post-op regiment. Perioperative Nurse will stay with patient to provide emotional support.
3. NURSING PROBLEM - DISCOMFORT - Alteration in comfort or physiological state related to surgical intervention. EXPECTED OUTCOME - Patient's pain controlled or is minimal and temperature will remain within normal limits. NURSING INTERVENTIONS - Evaluate severity of discomfort, assist patient to comfortable position and administer prescribed pain medication.
4. NURSING PROBLEM - DISFIGUREMENT - Disturbances in body image related to possible disfigurement or defect from the surgical procedure. EXPECTED OUTCOME - Patient expresses concerns appropriately and identifies others who are supportive. NURSING INTERVENTIONS - Explain location of incision and possible scarring, evaluate support systems and need for professional intervention.
5. NURSING PROBLEM - PROGNOSIS - Anxiety related to disease, surgery, and anesthesia and prognosis. EXPECTED OUTCOME - Patient verbalizes fear. NURSING INTERVENTIONS - Help patient recognize fears and explain procedure based on patient's questions.
6. NURSING PROBLEM - SKIN INTEGRITY - Implement skin integrity, injury, potential for related to positioning chemical, or electrical hazard. EXPECTED OUTCOME - Patient will not experience a break in skin integrity or muscular-Skeletal impairment 24 hours post-operatively as demonstrated by no redness, pain, bruises or skin abrasions under positioning devices, no pain or impairment of joint motion and no nerve deficit. NURSING INTERVENTIONS - Assist patient from gurney to table. Keep wrinkles or wet area from under the patients. Align patient properly. Utilize appropriate positional aides.
7. NURSING PROBLEM - 24-48 HOURS POST OP INFECTION - Injury, potential for, related to infection EXPECTED OUTCOME - Patient will be free of wound infection 72 hours post-operatively as demonstrated by no redness at incision site and clean. NURSING INTERVENTIONS - Apply appropriate skin prep. Enforce strict aseptic technique. - Monitor breaks in aseptic technique constantly.
8. NURSING PROBLEM - INJURY - Injury, potential for related to leaving foreign object in wound. EXPECTED OUTCOME - Patient will be free of injury as demonstrated by correct sponge and needle count. NURSING INTERVENTIONS - Perform timely and accurate sponge, sharp and needle counts prior to initial closure and final skin closure counts.
9. NURSING PROBLEM - KNOWLEDGE - Knowledge deficit regarding need for follow-up care. (outpatient). EXPECTED OUTCOME - Patient demonstrates understanding of instruction for wound care, signs and symptoms of infection with importance of follow-up appointment. NURSING INTERVENTIONS - Instruct patient on wound care, signs/symptoms of infections, how to contact appropriate resources for questions and/or problems.
10. NURSING PROBLEM - HYPOTHERMIA - Hypothermia, potential for, related to outdoor transport, cool Operating Room. EXPECTED OUTCOME - Patient's temperature will remain in the normal limits and will be normal prior to transport to the ward. NURSING INTERVENTIONS - Utilize extra blankets in transport. Use Blanketrol and/or Bair Hugger on the O.R. table. Use Bair Hugger in the PACU.
11. NURSING PROBLEM - LASER - Injury, potential for, related to the use of laser beam. EXPECTED OUTCOME - Patient will be free of laser injury to eyes, and free of injury from laser burns. NURSING INTERVENTIONS - During use of laser, the patients eyes are protected from the laser beam. Laser will be placed in stand-by mode when not in use. - Basin of water kept available in room. - Flammable plastics and or combustible materials are not used near laser site.
/es/ THEODORE HARRIS RN Signed: 03/01/2013 14:38 ,

E: Ambulates well Vital signs stable Dressing c/d/i Ice remained intermittently on surgical site Denies pain Taking liquids well Post-op instructions reviewed and understood All questions answered
POST-OP INSTRUCTIONS: Vasectomy Reversal (Krames On-Demand 8350) Each of a man's testicles makes sperm (male reproductive cells). Sperm travel from the testicles to the penis through one of two tubes called the vas deferens. On the way, sperm mix with other fluids to form semen, which leaves the body during ejaculation. During a vasectomy, each vas deferens is cut, blocking sperm from leaving the body. This makes you sterile (unable to make a woman pregnant). A vasectomy can sometimes be reversed, restoring the flow of sperm out of the body. After the Procedure You may need to stay in the hospital for several hours. When it's time to go home, have an adult family member or friend drive you. Once you're home: Take medication as directed to relieve any pain. To lessen the chance of swelling, stay off your feet as much as you can for the first day. Place an ice pack or bag of frozen peas (wrapped in a thin towel) on your scrotum for short amounts of time. This helps reduce swelling. Wear snug cotton briefs or an athletic supporter for extra support. Follow your doctor's instructions for showering and bathing. Ask your doctor when it's okay to have sex. Avoid heavy lifting or exercise for at least 2 weeks. Ask your doctor when you can return to work. Possible Risks and Complications Risks associated with anesthesia Infection (symptoms include fever, chills, drainage from the incision site, and pain) Internal bleeding of the scrotum (symptoms include increasing pain, excessive swelling, a large black-and-blue area, or a growing lump) Failure of the procedure to restore fertility
List Instructions: - No sex for 3 weeks - ice 20 mins on ice 20 mins off for 24 hours - Use scrotal support

REHAB ENHANCES: Motivation
